newsitem.title: JAPAN: Russia-Japan PGM talks may be held end-May - traders.
newsitem.headline: Russia-Japan PGM talks may be held end-May - traders.

text.p: Market talk has surfaced that long-delayed talks between Russia and Japanese customers on the renewal of export contracts for platinum group metals (PGM) may start at the end of this month, traders said on Thursday.

Some Japanese precious metal traders said they had heard from sources at Russia's PGM export agency, Almazjuvelirexport (Almaz), that a mission would be visiting Japan at the end of May, although a time schedule had yet to be decided.
"A source at Almaz told me they were likely to come to Japan for the export-contract talks for 1997, probably at the end of May," a trader said.
Some traders were sceptical because a visit by officials of the agency to Japan for export contract negotiations has already been delayed many times.
Japan is the world's largest PGM consumer and Russia provides about 60 percent of global supplies.
Contract talks between the two countries are usually held in mid-December, but have been held up by Moscow's failure to pass a decree setting out 1997 PGM export quotas.
In Moscow on Wednesday, Almaz said it believed the government decree had been signed at last.

"It happened in the last few days, although we have not yet received a copy of the decree," said Sergei Gorny, deputy director of the agency, adding that he could not therefore fully confirm that the decree had been signed.
Japan, unable to rely on term contract supplies from Russia, has boosted purchases of palladium in the Zurich spot market tightening the market considerably, traders said.
They said supply tightness, reflected in the persistently high lease rates, were not expected to ease significantly until after Russia resumes sales.
"Even if the mission arrives in Japan at the end of May, the first shipments to Japan under long-term contracts will probably be in July," an official at a bullion house said.
Palladium is used in catalytic converters for automobiles. But its main use is in electronics, which accounts for 60 percent of Japan's imports.

Japan's cumulative palladium imports in the first three months of 1997 amounted to 26.81 tonnes, up from 20.54 tonnes in the same period a year earlier, according to the latest data from Japan's Ministry of Finance.
Traders said the higher imports could be attributed to concern over Russian metal supplies, and were not signs of stronger Japanese demand.
